## üß© Puzzle

- The 2016-2022 Yellow Fever (YF) wave was **unprecedented**. It breached historical barriers, spreading from the Amazon through the Cerrado and into the densely populated **Atlantic Forest**.

- [Critical questions:]{.my-red}
  - _How did the virus persist through temperate winters and high-altitude regions (< 16¬∞C) that should have stopped transmission?_

## üå°Ô∏è Hypothesis

- We propose that **anomalous weather conditions** (climate change & variability) created temporary bridges for viral survival.
  - Warmer Winters: Prevented viral die-off in historically cold zones.
  - Altered Rainfall: Sustained vector populations during dry seasons.

## Background {.scrollable .smaller}

Temperature anomalies are the biological constraints of the virus. The viral incubation speed depends on temperature conditions ([Bellone and Failoux, 2025](https://www.frontiersin.org/journals/microbiology/articles/10.3389/fmicb.2020.584846/full); [Johanssen et al, 2010](https://www.ajtmh.org/view/journals/tpmd/83/1/article-p183.xml)).

```{r}
#| label: temp_R0_plot
#| fig-cap: "Relationship between temperature and R0 value for Yellow Fever virus transmission."
#| echo: false
#| fig-width: 6
#| fig-heigh: 4 
library(ggplot2)
temp_R0 <- data.frame(
  temp = c(18, 20, 22, 24, 25, 26, 28, 30, 32),
  R0_value = c(0.05, 0.3, 0.7, 0.95, 1.0, 0.95, 0.6, 0.2, 0.05)
)
ggplot(temp_R0, aes(temp, R0_value)) +
  geom_line(color="#0d88f0", size=2) +
  geom_point(shape=21, fill="#4bc8ef", color="#0d88f0", size=4) +
  labs(x = "Temperature (¬∞C)", y = "R0 value") +
  theme_light() + 
  theme(
    axis.title = element_text(size=14),
    axis.text = element_text(size=12))
```
:::

## üéØ Objectives {.smaller}

1. **Data Integration**
  - Building a comprehensive database linking NHP epizootics with fine-scale climate data (Temp, Rain, Wind, Vegetation).
2. **Spatio-Temporal Model**
  - Identifying "Thermal Corridors" and analyzing how microclimates allowed viral persistence during winter.
3. **Predictive Forecasting**
  - Developing a risk model using climate indicators as "early warning" signals for future outbreaks.

## Scientific Challenges

::::{.columns}

::: {.column width="50%"}
- ‚ö†Ô∏è **Sampling Bias**
  - Dead monkeys are only found where people look.  
  - [**Solution:** Occupancy Modeling & "Observer Bias" Covariates.]{.my-red}
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
- ‚ö†Ô∏è **Microclimate vs. Macroclimate**
  - Satellites miss the warm tree hollows where mosquitoes hide.
  - [**Solution:** Topographic Downscaling & Canopy Adjustment.]{.my-red}
:::
